thread.title: Six years on: Christchurch from the air
thread.title_full: Six years on: Christchurch from the air

title: Six years on: Christchurch from the air

organizations.name: feedback iain mcgregor/fairfax nz  new regent st

text:
Six years on: Christchurch from the air Last updated 21:00, February 21 2017 IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Re:Start Mall, right, became a haven for displaced business owners and a tourist attraction following the quakes. It will be replaced soon with permanent developments, such as Antony Gough's The Terrace project, left. 
Christchurch is transforming as anchor projects get underway . 
Visual journalist Iain McGregor took to the air to photograph the city as it looked on February 21, one day before the sixth anniversary of the devastating 2011 earthquake. Ad Feedback IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
New Regent St is again a popular hub in central Christchurch for locals and tourists, but several units remained closed following the quakes. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Latimer Square is the green park near the front of this image with the striking Cardboard Cathedral roof just to its left. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
The justice and emergency services precinct is scheduled to open in Christchurch's CBD mid-year. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
The colourful Margaret Mahy playground sits behind the trees to the front of the picture with directly behind it the empty city blocks which will make up the East Frame. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
The East Frame is shown in the foreground with the city centre behind. The Rendezvous Hotel is on the right and Christchurch Hospital is in the background on the right. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
The yet-to-be-reopened Rydges Hotel stands in the foreground with the empty convention centre site behind it on the left. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Ongoing road works holds up traffic on Durham St in central Christchurch. Otakaro Ltd says the work will be finished as soon as possible. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Work to restore the Christchurch Town Hall is continuing, but good progress is being made. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
The Hagley Oval cricket ground opened in September 2013. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
While parts of eastern Christchurch have been emptied out due to red zoning, other areas - like the Wigram Skies subdivision - are growing rapidly. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Houses bordering the residential red zone in Avondale, with the Avon River the central point. Decisions on what the red zone will be used for in the future have not yet been made. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Much of the Avon River is surrounded by greenery as it passes through the residential red zone. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Work is progressing on a major roading project near Christchurch Airport - creating a flyover of Memorial Ave at the intersection with State Highway 1 (Johns Rd). IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
A coastal path has been built alongside the causeway to Sumner and Redcliffs. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Peacocks Gallop, near Sumner, has lost the shipping containers that flanked the roadside for several years. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Evans Pass Rd, between Sumner and Lyttelton, remains closed due to significant damage and rockfall risk. - The Press
